document_title: G6PD deficiency: Causes, signs and treatments
subsection_name: thieu-men-g6pd.json_7_How to prevent hemolytic anemia due to G6PD deficiency
subsection_content:
According to Dr. Hanh, there is currently no cure for G6PD deficiency, however parents should note that there are many methods to help prevent the disease.
The best way to prevent risks is for parents to have their children undergo newborn screening by taking heel blood within the first 48-72 hours after birth. Children can have genetic diagnostic testing to help confirm disease status and severity, and provide genetic counseling information for parents and other family members such as: pre-marital and pre-pregnancy counseling.
Foods to avoid when lacking G6PD: Fava beans, red wine, Blueberries, soybeans...
Drugs that cause hemolysis and drugs that can cause hemolysis should be avoided.
If well-prevented, children are not exposed to agents that cause red blood cell breakdown and will still be healthy and develop equally with their peers.
Feed children foods rich in protein, iron, probiotics, healthy fats... to prevent hemolytic anemia due to G6PD deficiency.
